newsitem.title: UK: SOCCER-CHELSEA FOOTBALL CLUB'S HARDING DIES IN AIR CRASH.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-CHELSEA FOOTBALL CLUB'S HARDING DIES IN AIR CRASH.

text.p: Matthew Harding, multi-millionaire vice-chairman of Prime Minister John Major's favourite football team Chelsea, was killed in a helicopter crash on Tuesday night, the club said on Wednesday.
Harding, 42, was one of five people who died when the helicopter crashed into a field on the way back to London after a match between Chelsea and Bolton Wanderers in northwest England.
Earlier this year, Harding hit the headlines when he donated one million pounds ($1.60 million) to the opposition Labour Party, the biggest donation by an individual in the party's 90-year history.
The other crash victims had not been named early on Wednesday.
"It is confirmed that Matthew C. Harding...was killed last night," the company that owns Chelsea football club said in a brief statement.
The Eurocopter Twin Squirrel came down at about 11.00 pm (2200 gmt) on Tuesday evening in Cheshire, northwest England.
Residents reported hearing a helicopter engine in difficulties moments before and police ruled out speculation of a mid-air collision.
They first suspected Harding was among those killed when they found a charred football programme among the wreckage.
Harding, Britain's 89th richest man, began his working life as an office junior. By his early 40s he was the chairman of one of Britain's most profitable reinsurance companies, Benfield Group Ltd.
Although Chelsea's most prominent supporters include Major and former Conservative cabinet minister David Mellor, Harding was a supporter of the left-leaning Labour Party.
Labour leader Tony Blair described Harding's death as "an appalling tragedy."
"We all feel devastated for his family. He was so full of life and vigour and someone deeply committed to his country," Blair said.
Despite his great wealth and jet-set lifestyle, Harding endeared himself to Chelsea fans with his down-to-earth ways.
On match days, he would take a train into London and enjoy a beer in the Imperial Arms, a pub near Chelsea's Stamford Bridge football ground.
On the train he would stand in the buffet car chatting happily with fans about football. He watched matches from the public stand rather than the directors' box.
"He was a real football fan. Even a major business coup didn't give him the same thrill as Chelsea scoring," said Mellor, now a part-time sports broadcaster.
Last year, Harding was involved in a public feud with Chelsea chairman Ken Bates year over control of the club, but the dispute was finally resolved amicably.

He bought the Stamford Bridge ground in London's Fulham Road for 16.5 million pounds ($26 million) in 1995 and provided more cash for stadium improvements and to buy top overseas players including Italians Gianluca Vialli and Roberto Di Matteo and France's Franck Leboeuf.
Harding was married with two sons.
